Award.AwardTitle: High-Frequency EPR Studies of Strong Spin-Orbit Effects in Molecular Magnetism
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
The ability to rationally design magnetic molecules with properties tailored for specific applications represents a key goal within the molecular magnetism community. The past few years have seen remarkable breakthroughs in this regard, aided by the study of molecules comprised of magnetic ions with strong spin-orbit anisotropy, e.g., orbitally degenerate transition metals and lanthanides. In order to develop a theoretical understanding of these highly anisotropic magnetic materials, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) studies performed at very high fields and frequencies are essential. Recent instrument developments at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory (NHMFL), spanning unprecedented field and frequency ranges, will open up the EPR technique to many more materials of current interest. The information obtained will lead to improved theoretical understanding of the important static and dynamical processes that dictate the behavior of these materials. Strong collaboration with chemists will provide a crucial feedback loop, with the potential for transformative advances in molecule-based magnetic materials. Two female graduate students will participate in the research. Interdisciplinary workshops will also be organized, providing outstanding educational opportunities for a significant number of young researchers from diverse backgrounds, and a pipeline for knowledge transfer from within the NHMFL EPR program.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Fundamental studies of nano-scale molecular magnetic materials are essential for future advances in information processing technologies. The past few years have seen remarkable advances in this field, aided by investigations of molecular magnets based on heavier elements found further down the periodic table than those that have traditionally been of interest, e.g., rare-earth elements. The unusual properties of these materials that make them attractive for applications necessitate the development of new measurement techniques. This project will bring to bear on this problem the uniquely high magnetic fields available at the US National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, together with recently developed magnetic resonance methodologies, with a view to obtaining improved understanding of the physical processes that give rise to technologically useful properties. Strong collaboration between physicists and chemists will provide a crucial feedback loop, with the potential for transformative advances in molecule-based magnetic materials. Two female students will participate in the research. Interdisciplinary workshops will also be organized, providing outstanding educational opportunities for a significant number of young researchers from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This interdisciplinary project focused on the study of nanoscale magnetic molecules whose properties can be chemically engineered at the molecular level to give desired physical properties. These so-called molecular nanomagnets provide remarkable fundamental insights into magnetism at the nanoscale, while promising advances in information technologies. Two distinct thrusts were pursued: the first involved the potential use of magnetic molecules as the elementary memory units (bits) in classical computers, where information is stored in the magnetic polarization state of the molecule; the second explored the possibility of exploiting the quantum states of such molecules for information processing. Although the design criteria for classical and quantum memories (qubits) are somewhat different, they often involve tuning/optimizing the same interactions in molecular systems. Research performed under this award explored how choices of magnetic element, molecular geometry, surrounding host material, etc., influenced the stability of both classical and quantum information encoded into magnetic molecules. Results obtained from the project will be of interest to other research communities, including materials science, and inorganic/bioinorganic chemistry. Following are short descriptions of a few key outcomes.

A single atom has the potential to be the smallest unit of magnetic memory storage. But not just any atom, and not without exactly the right molecular environment. Only a few elements readily form magnetic compounds and, even then, the desired magnetic behavior can be undermined by surrounding non-magnetic atoms. This is where molecular nanomagnets come into play. By designing molecules containing just one or a handful of magnetic atoms, one can engineer the most important property for a magnetic memory. Called magnetic anisotropy, this property locks the north/south poles of the magnetic atom so that they point in only one of two directions. The magnetic anisotropy has to be strong in order to prevent thermal reorientation of the magnet and, therefore, a loss of its stored information. Work performed under this award demonstrated that one can achieve very strong anisotropy by placing a nickel atom in a very specific geometry within a molecule, paving the way towards very high-density information storage. Very high field magnetic resonance measurements performed at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory were then used to probe the resultant record magnetic anisotropy.

Following on from the above, it has long been believed that the presence of heavier atoms with principal quantum numbers ≥3 (3rd row of periodic table and below) was a fundamental requirement for magnetic ordering. The discovery of ferromagnetism in “light atom” organic radicals containing only H, C, and N appeared to violate this axiom, although the ordering temperatures and coercivities (ability to withstand external demagnetizing influences) are low. Work carried out under this award afforded organic radicals that display magnetic properties once thought to be exclusive to conventional metal-based magnets, albeit that they include heavier constituents such as sulphur and selenium. Theory and a newly developed high-pressure, high-field magnetic resonance technique were used to gain fundamental insights into the importance of spin-orbit coupling in these and other organic materials where this effect is usually considered to be small. The findings, published in an American Chemical Society review article, are applicable to topics as diverse as spintronics and topological spin phases.

The electron and nuclear spin states of magnetic molecules are among the many quantum systems being explored as building blocks for quantum computers. All such systems are challenged by decoherence—the destructive interaction of the quantum unit of information, or qubit, with its environment. Most sources of decoherence show up as fluctuations (noise) in the local magnetic field felt by each spin qubit. This project demonstrated that one can engineer molecules that have “sweet spots” where logic operations on the information-carrying spin states are insensitive to magnetic noise. This idea was demonstrated using a molecule containing a magnetic holmium ion encapsulated by a tungsten oxide cage. Strong enhancements in coherence were seen at so-called ‘atomic clock transitions’, named after the principle that gives atomic clocks their stability. This work, which has stimulated renewed interest in the use of molecules for quantum computing, was published in Nature and featured by several news organizations that target the general public, as well as Physics Update and Physics Today (69, 17, 2016) that target the wider physics community.

Finally, together with two colleagues, the PI secured a commitment from the Florida State University (FSU) administration to take over funding of the Maters-to-PhD Physics Bridge Program that was initially funded by the American Physical Society (co-PI, Hill). This program helps talented students from underrepresented groups who may lack preparation in some areas of undergraduate physics to transition to the PhD program. Five students were admitted in 2017, taking the total number of students in the program to 13.
